George De Forest Bartom has sold for Edward C. Edwards, to John W. Fife, for $65,000, the northeast corner of West Broadway and Price Street, 40 by 75. The buyer will erect a six story business building on the plot at once.

Details of the consolidation of the Knickerbocker Ice Company of Chicago were given yesterday at the office of Walston H. Brown Co., 40 Wall Street. The scheme unites about thirty Chicago ice companies under one management. The financial arrangements, involving about $7,000,000, were made by a New York syndicate. The deal is entirely foreign to the consolidation of the Maine ice companies.

WORCESTER, Sept. 28. -- One young singer scored a pronounced success, and one unfamiliar work found emphatic favor at the concerts of the music festival to-day. Both programmes were made up of novelties to the Worcester public, among them being the well-worn but always welcome Raff symphony, "Im Walde."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- Secretary Alger to-day made a verbal report to the President on the inspection of the army camps, which he has just concluded. On leaving the White House Secretary Alger refrained from specifically charging exaggeration of conditions of camp life, but said the results of the trip of inspection were quite satisfactory.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- In the absence of instructions, the naval vessels that have been in service during the war and have recently undergone overhauling have been restored to duty painted the same dull lead color that was adopted as the war paint of the Nation at the beginning of the trouble with Spain.

A dull explosion at Madison Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street last night was immediately followed by a fearful hissing like half a dozen locomotives blowing off steam, and then an immense column of flame shot up to a height of nearly forty feet and rapidly increased in thickness until it became over six feet in diameter, lighting up the avenue and intersecting street as far as the eye could reach and iluminating the entire district.

LONDON, Sept. 28. -- At the second day of the first October meeting at Newmarket to-day the Newmarket October Welter Handicap was won by the Lorillard-Beresford stable's three-year-old bay colt Elfin, which was ridden by Tod Sloane, the American jockey. Seven horses ran.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- State Department officials to-day confirmed the statement that they had taken steps to have arrested and held for examination the woman who landed yesterday at Liverpool, supposed to be Dr. Nancy Guilford, charged with being connected with the murder of Emma Gill at Bridgeport, Conn.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- Mr. De Quesada, who represents the Cuban Government in Washington, has received from Gen. Garcia a letter which reiterates the declarations of amity toward the United States recently attributed to Gen. Garcia in his conversation with Gen. Lawton and Gen. Wood, but does not make similar references to the non-existence of a Cuban Government.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 28. -- The sub-committee of the Committee on Platform met this afternoon and again this evening. The sub-committee has ten members, and Asa Bird Gardiner is its Chairman. After the meeting Col. Gardiner said:

Again the city and country were blessed yesterday with perfect Autumn weather. Upper Fifth Avenue and Broadway and the adjacent streets were thronged with shoppers on foot and in all sorts of traps. There was much driving in the Park in the afternoon, the theatres were crowded in the evening, and the golden sunlight and cool, exhilarating air made much stir and movement.

The Wool Exchange yesterday discontinued temporarily the auction sales on the floor of the Exchange and the use of its trading room. Allan Macnaughtan, the President of the Exchange, issued the following statement:

HAVANA, Sept. 28. -- The Spanish Commission to-day handed a communication to the American Commissioners requesting that a meeting of the commissions be held to treat orally upon matters of the utmost importance. Friday, Sept. 30, was agreed upon by the Americans for the meeting.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Sept. 28. -- An explosion of powder to-day in the rear of the four-story building at 410 North Fourth Street, occupied by C. W. McClain, fishing tackle and sporting goods, set the store on fire, caused its destruction, and resulted in the injury of seventeen persons, two of whom, Pauline Bruger and Florence Higby, employes of the McClain company, are dying at the City Hospital.

KINGSTOWN, St. Vincent, Sept. 16. -- A terrible storm passed over this island last Sunday, with the result that scarcely a building is left standing throughout the country, while about half of this place is destroyed. The whole country looks as if burned by lightning; hills and woods are bare as if cleared for planting. The cane crop is almost totally destroyed, and very little will be got out of the damaged cane.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 28. -- The Democratic State Convention met at 12:30 o'clock to-day in the Alhambra Rink, and was in session for just one hour. In that time its deliberations and proceedings threw absolutely no light upon the situation here. It left the ticket and the platform as problematical as they were last night.

JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 28. -- The local health officials admit that the yellow fever situation to-day is grave. No new cases are announced, but the physicians have several suspicious cases under surveillance, and it is expected that some of them will turn out to be yellow fever.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 28. -- The convention was called to order by Elliot Danforth, Chairman of the Democratic State Committee, and one of the leading candidates for the nomination for Governor. He took the chair at 12:30 o'clock, half an hour after the time set for the convention to begin. As soon as he appeared on the platform a great cheer went up from the crowd on the floor.

OYSTER BAY, L.I. Sept. 28. -- The town of Oyster Bay woke up this morning to find itself famous. Col. Roosevelt's fellow-townsmen were proud of the honor conferred upon him, and many lost no time in calling to congratulate the Republican candidate for Governor. Col. Roosevelt received them cordially, and told them their good wishes and confidence were most gratifying to him.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 28. -- The Van Wyck boom does not appear so large to-night as it did yesterday.

TACOMA, Washington, Sept. 28. -- Rather than return to Chicago penniless, James Gardiner committed suicide on the banks of the Stickeen River, near Glenora, on Aug. 28. After losing his outfit and becoming broken in health through hardships on the trail, he deliberately blew his brains out when within sight of Glenora, where he could have taken a steamer to Fort Wrangell, and thence to civilization.

The Protestant Episcopal Convention of the Diocese of New York began its one hundred and fifteenth annual session yesterday morning in Grace Chapel, 414 East Fourteenth Street, and will conclude it to-day. Some 200 delegates attended.

SALEM, Mass., Sept. 28. -- It is reported that a syndicate of capitalists is negotiating for the purchase of a number of electric railroads in New England. The first move of the syndicate is for the purchase of the Newburyport and Amesbury Electric Road. It is known that the latter road has been in a somewhat crippled condition regarding its rolling stock for some time.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 28. -- The Erie Railroad Company this morning announced a rate of $6 from Buffalo to New York, a reduction of $2.

A large dog in a fit of madness attacked a man yesterday afternoon at Third Avenue and Forty-fourth Street and bit him in the left hand and arm. The dog was shot, and the man, who was Henry Jackson of 135 East Forty-fourth Street, had his injuries cauterized.

SARATOGA, Sept. 28. -- The colored Republican State Convention was held here this morning and was presided over by Samuel Moran of New York City. Resolutions were adopted indorsing the action of the Republican State Convention held here yesterday, and promising the undivided support of the colored organization to the entire Republican State ticket, headed by Theodore Roosevelt.
PANA, Ill., Sept. 28. -- Striking union coal miners and imported negroes engaged in a pitched battle in the main street of this city to-night.

The small boy at the Battery is already sailing trial races for the coming international yacht race. Against the Shamrock are pitted the Manila, the Admiral Dewey, the Rough Rider, and other timely-named craft, fashioned with a jackknife. While the boat races are in progress other youngsters of different proclivities are engaged in catching fish with white twine and bent pins.

DEDHAM, Mass., Sept. 28. -- After an illness of over six weeks, Thomas F. Bayard, the first Ambassador from this country to Great Britain, died at 4:30 o'clock this afternoon at Karlstein, the Summer residence of his daughter, Mrs. Samuel D. Warren. His death was without pain, and the distinguished citizen merely passed from a semiconscious state to that of unconsciousness, and then ceased to breathe.

Umpire Connolly allowed the game to continue yesterday at the Polo Grounds after the eighth inning, although it was too dark to see the ball. The Philadelphias secured the lead in the eighth inning, and after the New Yorks had taken their turn at the bat the spectators started to leave the grounds. Umpire Connolly, however, refused to call the game, thus placing the spectators and players in danger of being hit by the ball.

Through the neglect or indifference of Government army officials the body of Private Patrick Daily, a member of Troop D, Second Volunteer Cavalry, who died in Brooklyn City Hospital last Saturday, has lain unembalmed in the hospital awaiting burial several days beyond the time allowed by law for a hospital to keep a body without a special permit.

The anti-American feeling in France at the present time ought not to discourage the preparations of this country for a large display at the Paris Exposition of 1900. The two interesting dispatches printed in THE TIMES of yesterday afforded a good view of the state of feeling in the French capital and gave good ground for estimating its importance.

LONDON, Sept. 28. -- The detectives have lost sight of the woman they shadowed after the arrival at Liverpool yesterday morning of the steamer Vancouver, from Montreal, and they are now ransacking the London hotels and boarding houses. Up to the present the police have not found any trace of the traveler.

DENVER, Col., Sept. 28. -- A prairie fire probably started by a spark from a locomotive, has burned over thousands of acres of grazing lands between Kiowa and Bijou Creeks in Morgan County and destroyed thousands of tons of hay. Ranchman R.W. Miller and his wife and child had a narrow escape from death.

James J. Corbett and Charles (Kid) McCoy, who, according to their own statements, have been endeavoring to pull off a prize fight for many weeks, met in an impromptu two-round bout in the lobby of the Gilsey House yesterday. There was no money in it for either pugilists or backers, and the kinetoscope was not on the scene.

Col. Theodore Roosevelt will formally open his campaign as the Republican candidate for Governor at a great ratification meeting to be held in Carnegie Hall next Wednesday evening under the auspices of the County Committee.

Cuba, he says, has become a "black man's country" almost or quite to the extent that Haiti is one, and he views the future with gloomy apprehensions.

Mr. ALGER comes back from the South to tell the President that the one serious trouble in connection with the camps is the young American soldiers' tendency to eat things that are not good for them, and especially to get them from what he calls "outside eating tents." This would be grotesque if it were not infuriating.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- Major Gen. Hamilton S. Hawkins, United States Volunteers, who commanded the division which captured San Juan Hill in the second day's fight at Santiago, has been appointed a Brigadier General in the regular army, to fill the vacancy caused by the retirement of Gen. William M. Graham.

Harry Watson, twenty-five years old, a private of Company D, Fourteenth Regiment New York Volunteers, was removed yesterday, together with his wife, from their home at 326 Twelfth Street, Brooklyn, to the Long Island College Hospital, Brooklyn. Both were in a very weak condition, due to lack of food and proper nourishment. It is said they had not had anything to eat for several days.

Clothing merchants in East Broadway and elsewhere have lost nearly $10,000 worth of goods through the operations of Reuben Goldstein, a truckman, according to the allegations of the police, who claim they have trace of cases worth $6,000 spirited away by Goldstein. They believe other victims of his trickery are yet to be heard from.

The first conviction under the law relating to mock auctions was obtained in the Court of General Sessions before Judge Fitzgerald yesterday, when Peter Korn and Pauline Silverstein, an auctioneer and one of his accomplices, pleaded guilty to an indictment charging them with conspiracy to cheat. They were fined respectively $100 and $25.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 29. -- The biggest monolith ever quarried in the United States will mark the family lot of John D. Rockefeller in Lake View Cemetery. The monument will be studiously plain, but it will attract great attention from its mammoth size. It will be erected in November by Joseph Carabelli, who has been awarded the contract.

Lions are gathering in the path of the men who are furthering the project to run an independent State ticket this Fall. Leading members of the Citizens' Union have seized the opportunity afforded by Col. Roosevelt's declination of the independent nomination and the consequent demoralization of the independents' plans, to utter an emphatic protest against the claims and methods of the campaigners.

The trouble that has been brewing in the congregation of the Episcopal Church of the Intercession, One Hundred and Fifty-eighth Street and the Boulevard, for several months has been brought to a sudden and unexpected climax by the resignation of the rector, the Rev. Henry Dixon Jones. His resignation has been accepted by a unanimous vote of the Vestry, and he will vacate the pulpit in December.

He knows political principles, and he adheres to them with tenacity and with fidelity.

There were five failures in Company I and one each in Companies C and F and in the Hospital Corps.

BOSTON, Sept. 29. -- Radcliffe College opened this morning with a large entering class, as well as with many returning students. By 10 o'clock Fay House was well filled witl gayly chaffing, Bright-faced girls, all bent on the business of registering.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 29. -- Keeler, Baltimore's crack fielder, sprained his ankle in to-day's game with Brooklyn. The injury, according to his physician, will keep him out of the game for more than a week. Hunt's umpiring gave much dissatisfaction, and caused two arguments, which resulted in Kelley and McGann being put out of the game.

LONDON, Sept. 29. -- At the third day's racing of the first October meeting at Newmarket to-day the three-year-old bay filly Mandorla, by Hampton, out of Almond, finished first in a welter handicap, a neck ahead of the four-year-old chestnut colt Kirschwasser, by Kirkham, out of Gold Wave, ridden by Tod Sloane, the American jockey.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- Brig. Gen. Henry M. Duffield, comanding the separate brigade of the Second Army Corps, has submitted to the War Department his report of the operations of his command during the Santiago campaign. The report, which was made public by the department to-night, was delayed, owing to Gen. Duffield having been taken sick with yelow fever and removed to the hospital from Siboney on the 10th of July.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 29. -- David B. Hill, whom Tammany Hall had expected it would practically ignore in the making of its programme for the convention, proved himself to-day as great a power in the party organization of the State as he has ever been. It was Mr. Hill who forced Richard Croker to compromise with Kings County and agree to the nomination of Justice Van Wyck.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 29. -- The Chicago platform Democrats, who in conference last night adopted resolutions instructing the Committee on Organization, composed of one member from each Senatorial district in the State, to place in nomination a full ticket by petition, should the convention to-day fail to affirm the Chicago platform, had another meeting to-day, after the action of the regular Committee on Resolutions became known.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- The New York team to-day gave the most flagrant exhibition of disorganization and amateur playing probably ever seen on the Washington grounds. At the end of the sixth inning Warner was put out of the game. Joyce redistributed the players, with the result that but two men remained as originally placed.

Pierre Humbert, a retired merchant, seventy-nine years old, of 6 West Fifty-third Street, was taken with a fainting spell at the corner of Broadway and Cedar Street yesterday afternoon, and but for Policeman Slattery of the Broadway Squad, who ran to his assistance, he would have fallen to the pavement.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Sept. 29. -- Lieut. Elsworth P. Bertholf, second officer of the Bear on her trip last Winter to the rescue of the whalers imprisoned in the arctic regions near Point Barrow, arrived home last night. He says the trip overland, after leaving the Bear, was a severe one, but those who took part in it were amply repaid by the welcome they received from the seventy-eight imprisoned whalers.

In stepping down from the bench of the Supreme Court to become a candidate for the Governorship, Judge VAN WYCK has at least one advantage over a nominee drawn from the field of active politics or from the obscurity of private life. He appears before the people already equipped with a certificate of character and ability which inspires confidence in his own party and successfully meets the earlier challenges of the opposition.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 29. -- Fully 15,000 spectators were present at the Westchester County Fair and Horse Show to-day. In Class 2, trotters, the first prize of $50 was captured by May K., owned by William M.V. Hoffman. The red ribbon was taken by Henry P., owned by Charles F. Wood.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 29. -- The new Democratic State Committee met at the Yates House soon after the adjournment of the convention, and organized by the election of Frank Campbell of Bath, Chairman; John M. Carlisle of Watertown, Secretary; John F. Gaynor of Syracuse, Treasurer; Charles R. De Freest of Troy, clerk, and Leonard Wager of Troy, Sergeant at Arms.
A memorial tablet in her honor, is Richmond's latest tribute of affection to the memory of Miss Winnie Davis. It is to be placed in St. Paul's Church, near the memorial window to her father.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 29. -- When dinner was announced at Crossways, Mrs. Stuyvesant Fish's Summer residence, last night, the butler was not on hand, and search was made for him. He was finally found, and it was evident that he had paid frequent visits to the wine cellar.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 29. -- The convention hall presented a more cheerful scene to-day than yesterday. The Alhambra Rink was filled from stage to steps. The aisles were occupied by delegates or spectators, and hundreds of persons stood against the railing of the galleries or hung about the platform. A few more decorations had been added to the hall, a new banner hung here and there, and a few more pictures placed in conspicuous positions.

Forty-eight golfers of the fifty-three who turned in scores yesterday for the long thirty-six-hole medal play on the links of the Queens County Golf Club at Glen Cove, L.I., qualified for the three silver cups offered by the club as the trophies for its annual open tournament. The eligible contestants were divided into batches of sixteen.

Charles Malcek, twenty-four years old, a private in the United States Marine Corps on furlough, was arrested at Thirtieth Street and Broadway last night by two Central Office detectives as a fugitive from justice. Malcek is a Bohemian, and prior to Oct. 4, 1897, was a porter in the employ of the National Express Company in Jersey City.

If yesterday's performance of the alleged crack three-year-old of the West, Lieber Karl, is the best he can do, the claims of the Westerners who heralded him as a world beater -- the peer of Hamburg and of all the other good three-year-olds of the East -- will not be counted for much, for Lieber Karl ran a very "doggy" race at a mile and was beaten by Swiftmas in a gallop.

Three hundred and seventy officers and men of the cruiser Brooklyn who played such a gallant part in the destruction of Cervera's fleet off Santiago Harbor, stood shoulder to shoulder yesterday afternoon in the great drill hall of the Twenty-third Regiment Armory in Brooklyn, and withstood a far more trying ordeal.

Borgstede Kienke have sold, for George Stolz, for $18,000, the four-story flat 546 East One Hundred and Fifty-fifth Street, 25 by 75 by 100; also, for J.A. Prigge, for $8,000, the three-story dwelling, on the north side of Ash Street, 175 feet west of Morris Avenue.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 29. -- Caryl Frazee, who was the heroine of a bicycle elopement on the Fourth of July two years ago, asked Judge Lambert in the First Criminal Court to-day to compel her husband, Harold Frazee, to turn over to her a trunk containing her clothing and effects. The trunk was at the home of her husband's parents, where she had been living since the return of the couple from their elopement.

Richard Mansfield has bought from Alonzo B. Kight, the builder, the five-story limestone front dwelling 316 Riverside Drive, on a lot 22 feet front by 100 feet in depth. The price paid is reported as $80,000.

The return of Summer yesterday morning effected a curious and sudden change in the aspect of Fifth Avenue and the adjacent up-town fashionable streets. Where on Wednesday they were thronged with pedestrians and shoppers, the sunny side of the way was yesterday deserted and there was a marked diminution in the number of people visible.

Frank Van der Stucken, the dean of the Cincinnati College of Music and Director of the Symphony Orchestra, returned from his vacation of five months in Europe yesterday on the Red Star Liner Friesland. Mr. Van der Stucken said he had visited Germany, Switzerland, France, and Belgium, and in all of those countries he failed to hear any new musical works which were worthy of introduction to this country.

REYNOLDS, Ga., Sept. 30. -- Gen. John B. Gordon, Commander in Chief of the United Confederate Veterans, is at his plantation near here resting and at intervals pursuing his literary work. In the first game, the home players kept three runs ahead, and did not exert themselves at the bat as long as the margin was maintained.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 30. -- Clarence J. Boyd and William Henry Jones, trading as Boyd, Jones Co., retail and wholesale dealers in rubber articles and supplies, made an assignment this afternoon for the benefit of creditors.

LONDON, Sept. 30. -- At the fourth day's racing of the first October meeting at Newmarket to-day, a selling plate for three-year-olds and upward was won by the six-year-old brown gelding Eau Gallie, by Iroquois, out of Dutchess. The four-year-old bay colt The Wake, ridden by Ted Sloane, the American jockey, finished second.

PARIS, Sept. 30. -- The United States Peace Commission has taken possession of its working quarters, a suite of seven rooms on the ground floor of the Hotel Continental, at the corner of the Rue de Rivoli and the Rue Royal, commanding the Tuileries Gardens, formerly used by the ex-Empress Eugenie.

MONTAUK, L.I., Sept. 30. -- The day for the last man to leave Camp Wikoff has been set for Oct. 15. Troops A and F of the Secand Cavalry, with 1,000 horses, started today for Huntsville. Troops C and D will leave to-morrow with 900 horses and mules. The remainder of the regiment will leave camp on Monday.

May one interject a gentle protest against the use of the phrase "Christian name" in this connection? The Romans said praenomen, the French say prenom, and we have used the word "forename" for the last 365 years. It is as incorrect to speak of the Christian name of a Jew, for example, as it would be hopeless to expect a Christmas card from a Jewish rabbi.

The archaeologist meets grim surprises. In England some one was exploring certain openings which in the most remote time had been made so that flint could be obtained by primitive man for the manufacture of stone implements. The searcher found a rude pick made of a deer's horn, and on the crumbling wooden handle the imprint of the hands, the dirt creases, showing when the workman had last grasped his rude tool.

Henry Cabot Lodge in his "Life of Alexander Hamilton" describes in a very graphic manner how Hamilton, during a murder trial, in which he suspected one of the witnesses of being guilty of the crime, resorted to the trick of placing candies at either side of the witness box while he cross-examined the individual.

Scott Inglis, who was formerly a member of Julia Arthur's company, committed suicide last evening by shooting himself in the heart at his boarding house, 44 West Twenty-seventh Street. Inglis was in the habit of going on periodic carousals, and over a week ago he began drinking heavily and neglected to attend rehearsals.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 30. -- At the September session of the Supreme Court, held here to-day, Col. Samuel R. Honey was accorded preference to present the cases of Elbridge T. Gerry and Robert Goelet for determination of citizenship under the new statute of Rhode Island.
CAIRO, Sept. 30. -- The Cameron Highlanders, which it was reported Gen. Kitchener had left at Fashoda, are returning here.

The plan of Gen. WOOD to which we recently referred of establishing a mounted police in Santiago has been approved at Washington and is now being gradually carried out. It appears also that the Government is considering the extension of the plan over the interior provinces of Cuba as fast as the Spanish garrisons are withdrawn.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 30. -- Fanned to fury by gales, the forest fires are sweeping through the timber land of Wisconsin. Great havoc has resulted, and it is feared the work of destruction is but begun.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- Secretary Alger has received a long letter from Gen. Leonard Wood, Military Governor of Santiago. It is personal to a great extent, but deals with many questions of interest to the public, and Secretary Alger has allowed some extracts to be published.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30. -- Dr. F.A. Todd, Assistant Superintendent of the Ohio Insane Asylum, at Toledo, Ohio, died at the Pasteur Institute in this city at 7 o'clock tonight from hydrophobia. He was bitten by a mad dog which got into the asylum grounds and which threatened to bite the patients.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- The Commissioner of Internal Revenue has held that the provision of the new war revenue tax which states that the amount of the annual tax required to be paid by bankers "shall, in all cases, be computed on the basis of the capital and surplus for the preceding year," relates only to bankers who have been in business during the preceding year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- The option granted to holders of Pacific Railroad bonds becoming due Jan. 1, 1899, to receive payment in full with interest, less a rebate of one-half of 1 per cent., terminates with the month of September. The department, however, extends the option through the month of October to Nov. 1.

Regarding the charter and purchase of lake vessels for use on the Atlantic Coast in coal carrying, Manager Sherwood of the Atlantic Transportation Company of 1 Broadway, said yesterday that the thirty-five vessels procured varied from 1,000 to 5,000 tons. They were adapted to the requirements of the company's business and were secured under more favorable terms than vessels could be secured here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- The condition of the Roman Catholic Church throughout the country will be considered at the annual meeting of the Archbishops of the United States, which will be held at the Catholic University, beginning Oct. 11. A full attendance of the leading figures of the Church is expected, including Archbishop Keane, who has come from Rome to attend the annual gathering.

The Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst, accompanied by his wife, arrived home yesterday morning on the White Star liner Britannic after a long vacation abroad. Much of the time he spent in Switzerland mountain climbing. Dr. Parkhurst returns with health greatly improved, and has an air of physical strength that was noticeably lacking before he went abroad.

DENVER, Col., Sept. 30. -- The Weather Bureau can offer no hope for those on the western slope whose homes and crops are threatened by the forest fires. There are no indications whatever of rain. Throughout Eagle County high winds have prevailed, giving a fresh impetus to the forest fires. In consequence, new territory is being devastated.

Spreckels, and is now in the hands of a syndicate of bankers and brokers, the new Board of Directors being as follows: Edward Pollitz, President, E.M. Walsh, Albert Meyer, R.G. Brown, and Charles Sutro.

Wall Street has had a blind pool week. Out of a total of nearly 500,000 shares traded in each day Stock Exchange transactions in trust stocks have daily averaged a quarter of a million. All have been weak, some of them showing almost utter demoralization. One stock -- Tobacco Trust -- has fallen 30 points.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 1. -- The football season for West Point opened here this afternoon in a game between the cadets and the team from Tufts College. The weather was a trifle warm but otherwise the conditions were excellent for the game, and a crowd of 3,000 persons was present. The game began at 4 o'clock, and was made up in twenty and fifteen minute halves.

There was a benefit at the Eldorado Casino, in Weehawken, last night for the purpose of raising funds to carry the case of Murderer Edward Clifford through the United States Courts on appeal. The promoters of the benefit, friends of the condemned man, realized enough money, they said, to carry on his fight for a long time to come.

WASHINGTON, Oct 1. -- Secretary Hay has been in receipt of cable advices from Judge Day, President of the American Peace Commissioners, in which he says that the business of the commission is proceeding in the most satisfactory manner. The utmost courtesy has been shown the members of the commission by the French officials, and every facility for the accomplishment of the work with which they are charged has been placed at their command.

PARIS, Oct. 1. -- The American and Spanish Peace Commissions assembled for their first business session at 2 o'clock this afternoon in the rooms assigned to them for their deliberations at the French Foreign Office, on the Quai d'Orsay. A special entrance is set apart for the use of the Commissioners in order to furnish them with every privacy and convenience possible.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 1. -- The announcement of Nancy Guilford's arrest caused a small sensation here. Passersby thronged around the boards on which the bulletins were displayed, and general satisfaction was expressed.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 1. -- Thomas Hardy and Daniel McKelvey, two employes of the Laflin Rand Powder Company, at its works at Mountain View, were killed to-day by an explosion. They were practically roasted alive where they stood. Hardy and McKelvey were expert grinders and had charge of the machinery in the "corning" mill, where the powder is reduced into grains. Hardy lived in Mountain View and McKelvey in Lincoln Park. Both leave families.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 1. -- Col. Samuel Sturgis, United States Army, has arrived in St. Paul from Manila, which place he left in company with Gen. Babcock, United States Army, Aug. 30, arriving in San Francisco, on Sept. 22. Col. Sturgis has been the Assistant Adjutant General of the Army Corps at Manila, and of the Department of Manila, under Gen. Merritt.

CHIPPEWA FALLS, Wis., Oct. 1. -- August Mason of this city, one of the most extensive loggers in Wisconsin, returned today from a trip to his camps at Cedar Lake, Barren County. He had an exciting time with forest fires, and reports the entire loss of all his camps and outfits at Cedar Lake. He also believes that four of his men have lost their lives in the flames.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 1. -- This week has been productive of great results in the football circles of Princeton University. Within six days the coaches have gotten together a team that bids fair to do honor to the orange and black before the end of the season. That such rapid strides in the formation of the team should be made would have been believed impossible in past years.

SAN JUAN DE PUERTO RICO, Oct. 1. -- The Spanish transport Isla de Panay arrived here this morning, and a second transport is expected to-morrow or Monday. These, with a hospital ship which will come from Havana to remove a number of sick troops, will carry away about 3,500 Spanish soldiers.

In the southern part of Tyrol, where the foaming waters of the Adige and the Passer unite in a stormy embrace, lies 'beautiful Meran, imbedded in roses and grapevines. Magnificent villas surround it as with a costly girdle, and the heights above are studded with castles and ancient strongholds.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- The battleship Illinois will be launched the 4th of October, at noon, at the yard of the Newport News Shipbuilding Company. This fine ship, designed in the Bureau of Construction and Repair, is a sister of the Alabama, building at Cramps' yard in Philadelphia, and also of the Wisconsin, building at San Francisco by the Union Iron Works.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 1. -- Harvard defeated Williams this afternoon by only eleven points. As it was the first game of the season, the score is considered very unsatisfactory, and the eleven will have to take a big "brace" to get into 'Varsity form.

CINCINNATI, Oct 1. -- Hawley kept the St. Louis' hits scattered in the first game and won. Coleman, once a St. Louis pitcher, but now a member of the Sixth Regiment, pitched the second game for the Cincinnatis, and was hit hard in the last three innings. Scores:

SANTIAGO DE CUBA, Oct. 1. -- El Porvenir publishes to-day a three-column article reviewing the improved conditions and the better feeling existing between the Cubans and Americans in consequence of Gen. Garcia's reception here by Gen. Wood on Sept. 22, and the appointment of Gen. Demetrio Castillo as special chief of Gen. Wood's Cuban staff to represent him in dealing with the insurgents in the country districts.

" Ted" Sloane, the American jockey, has during the past few years been a very successful jockey. Before he became popular he was considered a very ordinary rider, but now Princes, Dukes, Earls, and members of Parliament are clamoring for his services. He has astonished the English turfmen and jockeys not only by the style of riding which is peculiar to him, but also by his great success.

I KNEW George Arbuthnot pretty well for two years -- ever since he had been married, in fact -- and considered him a rising fellow in the literary world. He had not done anything very great, but his work was distinctly promising, and his name was gradually making itself known.

That the challenge of Sir THOMAS LIPTON for the famous America's Cup would stimulate the sport of yachting on this side of the Atlantic was a foregone conclusion, hut it was hardly to be expected that it would act as an inducement to Englishmen to try their fortunes in other competitions in these waters.

ITHACA, Oct. 1. -- "To foster the progress of hydraulic science" is the object for which thousands of dollars have been spent in building and equipping the new hydraulic laboratory which is open for use this Fall at Cornell University.

The remodeled Democratic Clubhouse, at 617 Fifth Avenue, was formally opened last night by a reception and "house warming." The occasion was made more notable by the passage of resolutions indorsing the ticket nominated and the platform adopted by the recent convention at Syracuse. Justice Augustus Van Wyck, the nominee for Governor, and Elliot Danforth, the nominee for Lieutenant Governor, were present, and both received hearty greetings.

Girls are by far too apt to thoughtlessly punch holes in the business prospects of the young men of their acquaintance. They work this mischief in various ways. They consider it "great fun" to step to a telephone, for example, and "ring up" some young man while he is at his office, only to send him some unnecessary message or indulge in some flippant talk.

The Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences will open the season with a lecture in the art building to-morrow evening. The first general meeting of the members of the Institute will be held Thursday evening at 8:15 o'clock, when President Charles Kendall Adams of the University of Wisconsin will deliver an address on "The Lessons Taught by the Recent Spanish-American War."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 1 -- This was the closing day of the annual Westchester County Fair and Horse Show. The horses did not receive much attention to-day, however, for the baby show was held, and there were about fifty of the prettiest children in the county entered for the prizes. All were in the grand stand, and there were but two classes for girls and two for boys.

MOZART'S fascinating musical phrases have been heard again at Munich, says a critic in The Pall Mall Gazette, and continues: The festival has come and gone, and it is possible now to review the experiences of that festival, and to record some deliberate opinions formed outside that golden atmosphere, and with a fervor of helpless enthusiasm calmed by reflection and thought.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- The comparative statement of the Government receipts and expenditures for September shows the total receipts to have been $39,778,070 and the expenditures $54,223,921. This statement takes no account of the receipts from the war loan. The receipts for September, 1897, were $21,933,098, showing an increase of over $17,000,000 for the month.
All the details have been worked out for the consolidation of the principal fisheries of the great lakes, and this combination is now an accomplished fact.

The reports of Consular officers on the commercial relations of the United States contain some facts which should be impressed on Congress. One of these facts, frequently reiterated, relates to our system of weights and measures. Mr Morris, the Consul at Ghent, Belgium, brings this out prominently in a recent report. * * * From the time of Washington to this day the evils of our system, or lack of system, have been pointed out.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1. -- The international cricket match between the picked Philadelphia Gentlemen eleven and Capt. P.F. Warner's English team is still undecided, and considerable interest is carried over to the play of Monday, when it will be shown whether the Englishmen can top the score of the Philadelphians.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- A dispatch from Major Gen. Brooke, comanding the American troops at Ponce, Puerto Rico, informs the War Department that the Panama sailed for the United States yesterday and that she had on board 170 convalescent soldiers and 5 officers.

A dense fog off Sandy Hook placed a temporary embargo on shipping yesterday. The first vessel to reach Quarantine was the Panama steamship Advance at 1:10 P.M. She and the steamers San Marcos and Avery Hill were held outside the Hook from early morning. All outgoing steamers were more or less delayed, and the steamer La Gascogne while passing out over the bar at low tide touched bottom.

The sixty-first games of the New York Athletic Club were held Yesterday at the club grounds, at Travers Island. Ideal weather and an excellent programme served to make the event one of the most successful in the history of the club. Nearly 5,000 lovers of athletic sports were gathered on the grounds and applauded the struggles of some of the best amateur athletes in the country.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 1. -- In spite of several shortcomings the forty-first music festival affords ground for encouragement and satisfaction. The aim of the management has been higher than ever before, and the seal of public approval has been put unmistakably upon it. It is true that some of the works selected for performance were not adequately rendered, but it is apparent that the festival forces are adequate to the task imposed upon them.

Malaria claims more victims than any other disease. The annual aggregate runs into several millions. A scientific commission has been appointed to investigate the mode of dissemination of malarial poison.
QUEBEC, Oct. 1. -- For two weeks a wrecking crew and divers have been at work trying to raise the hull of an old ship in the Quebec Harbor, near the Queen's wharf.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 1. -- The second week of football practice at Harvard, though merely preliminary work, has been very satisfactory. Both Head Coach Forbes and Capt. Dibblee proclaim the outlook bright, and McMasters who has temporary charge of the physical condition of the men, is much pleased with the health of the squad in general.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Oct. 1. -- Official reports absolutely contradict the stories in circulation about Maroon outbreaks sent out from Port Antonio. The only foundation for the reports was that a small party of Maroons attempted to seize some disputed property, which necessitated the forcible ejection of the Maroons by the police.

There is no danger of the people of the United States or of the world suffering for lack of wheat now or at any time in the future, according to the officials and statisticians of the Agricultural Department. This statement was drawn out of them to-day by The Star in reply to certain gloomy forebodings as to the future of wheat, made recently by Sir William Crooke, the President of the British Association in England.

The appointment last week of four Examiners, who, with Mr. MAXWELL, the Superintendent, will constitute the board for the examination of teachers, practically completes the working organization of the present school system. By the beginning of the new year twenty-two new school buildings, which will give seats for some forty thousand children, will be ready for opening in the territory of the old City of New York.

Miss Alice Nielsen, who so successfully invaded the sacred and almost inaccessible realms of stardom at Wallack's Theatre last Monday night as Irma, Musette, and Fedor alternately in Harry B. Smith's and Victor Herbert's new opera, "The Fortune Teller," had many amusing adventures during her long vacation last Summer.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., Oct. 1. -- This city had a visitation of fire this afternoon, which threatened for four hours to destroy the entire business district. The wind was blowing at the rate of forty-five miles an hour from the Southwest when the fire started at tht Denver and Rio Grande freight depot at the foot of Cuchares Street at 2:10 o'clock P.M., and the flames spread with great rapidity.

LONDON, Oct. 1. -- The Emperor of China is known to have lately shown leanings toward Christianity, and it was recently reported that he had burned the Confucian classics in the palace.

READING, Penn., Oct. 1. -- As the Pennsylvania Gubernatorial campaign progresses it is characterized by more extraordinary features. Dr. S.C. Swallow, the Prohibition candidate and his party leaders have cast prohibition into the background and are making "honest government" their battle cry.

Capt. Knipe and Acting Detective Betts of the Flatbush Precinct, Brooklyn, went sleuthing yesterday morning in suck a crafty way that they aroused the suspicions of the residents, and were "held up" by eight citizens with revolvers. Burglars have been prowling around the Vanderveer Park section, and the residents have agreed that if one of them sees a burglar he shall fire a pistol as a signal to rouse the neighborhood.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 1. -- With flags at half-mast and draped in mourning, with the closing of business houses, and with other demonstrations of sorrow, Wilmington to-day committed to the grave the mortal remains of Thomas Francis Bayard.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 1. -- John A. Cole, Republican leader of Fulton County, and who was Chairman of the Fulton County delegation to the Saratoga Convention, has been missing for three weeks, and policemen and private persons are looking for him. For three years he had a position behind the clerk's desk in the State Assembly, the last two years as index clerk. His home is at Northville.

NEWPORT, Oct. 1. -- Albert Bullock, who was discharged, with the aid of the police, Thursday night, from Crossways, the Summer home of Mr. and Mrs. Stuyvesant Fish, where he was employed as butler, and who was put on the Wickford boat, to be sent to New York, returned to Newport yesterday.

Fair ladies in the Middle Ages embroidered the banners under which their knights fought, and, although flagmaking now is put upon a business basis, it has been the work of women in the United States since the first flag of the country was made down to the present day.

There is some reason for calling an owl the bird of wisdom; and yet there is cause for wondering if the crow is not mentally his superior. Crows are not disheartened by the gloom of late Autumn. If the fog is too dense to fly through it, they rise above it or trot about the ground, discussing the situation with their fellows.

LONDON, Oct. 1. -- There has been a lull in the Dreyfus excitement since the appeal in the case and the incriminating documents were sent to the Court of Cassation, whose decision, however, will probably not be rendered until January. The preliminary proceeding will take three weeks, and the matter is not likely to formally come before the court before the end of October.

Chicago seems overburdened with cranks. The latest outbreak is from a crowd of vegetarians who "demand" that no meat shall be served at the banquets which are to be a feature of the approaching peace jubilee in that city.

A business man of the Borough of Manhattan decided to move into the suburbs some time ago and bought a house with a large lot of ground around it, near Jamaica, L.I. Wishing to beautify his grounds and also to raise something useful, he wrote to his Congressman asking him to send him some flower seeds for his garden and some vegetable seeds for his spacious back yard lot.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- With all the preparation at the War Department for an exhaustive investigation into the conduct of the war, and in spite of assurances by members of the President's commission and others that the inquiry will be thorough and fearless, it is easy to find people right in the War Department who do not look for a satisfactory conclusion of the investigation.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 1. -- The Yale-Wesleyan football game at Yale Field this afternoon resulted in a victory for Yale by the score of 5 to 0. The game was a surprise to both elevens, to Yale because of the small score, and to the Wesleyan men because they found themselves even stronger than anticipated.

Every true friend of woman -- and who of us would like to deny that title? -- must wish the managers of Barnard College the best of luck in the matter of subscriptions during the next forty-eight hours. If in that time the $57,900 needed to pay off the debt of the noble institution shall be subscribed, the college will have the benefit of an endowment fund of $100,000 yielding an income of $5,000 annually.

PARIS, Oct. 1. -- A duel between M. Charles Ernest Paulmier, Deputy from Calvados, and M. Turot of the Lanterne was fought this morning, rapiers being the weapons used. M. Turot was thrice wounded in the thigh and side, and M. Paulmier was slightly wounded on the lip.

But it is these very eyes of Kitchener's that Salisbury needs near him now, and it is not an unfair guess that if the Soudan could only spare the man who is its born Governor General his place is at the War Office here.

The body of the Rev. Dr. John Hall, late pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, who died in Ireland recently, was brought to this city and to his old home, the church parsonage, yesterday. It arrived on the Cunard Liner Etruria early in the evening, and with the remains came the widow and her son, Prof. Robert W. Hall, who had been abroad for his health.

MERIDEN, Conn., Oct. 1. -- From official sources it was learned to-day that the great combination of the silver and silver-plated ware manufacturing interests of the United States and Canada, under the auspices of the International Silver Company, is no longer a possibility along the lines upon which negotiations for several months past have been conducted.

The reviewing stand was at the Prospect Park Plaza, and at least 40,000 persons crowned the hills and slopes and massed themselves in the wide roadways leading to the plaza and in the plaza itself.

RICE LAKE, Wis., Oct. 1. -- Relief parties are now out through the border districts south and west of this city. The loss of life from the disastrous forest fires cannot now be estimated, but it will be great. The work of getting to the burned districts is slow, as all the bridges are down. Over 100 persons are missing. Many dead bodies have been found, and they are burned beyond recognition.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1. -- While leaning over a casket yesterday taking a last look at the remains of Minnie Graef, a girl friend, Minnie Budelski fell forward over the casket and died instantly. Miss Budelski and Minnie Graef had been constant companions since babyhood.

Eshbaugh, President of the New England Loan and Trust Company, was solved yesterday when the body of the financier was found in the North River near Hoboken. There were upon it no marks of violence, and jewelry and papers carried by the dead man were found with him.

FALL RIVER, Oct. 2. -- In a heavy fog in the Sound early this morning the Fall River Line steamer City of Brockton ran down the schooner Richard Hill of and from Thomaston, Me., bound for New York, with a cargo of lime. The crew of the schooner was rescued and brought to this city.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Oct. 2. -- Much alarm was occasioned here to-day by the hoisting of hurricane signals by the Weather Bureau. It was feared that much damage would be done, but such was not the case. During the day the wind reached a velocity of sixty-two miles, and the tide rose two and a half feet above normal.

The Rev. Dr. George R. Van De Water, rector of St. Andrew's Episcopal Church, at Fifth Avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-seventh Street, and Chaplain of the Seventy-first Regiment, preached to his congregation yesterday morning for the first time since his return from the front. Admission to the church was by ticket, and so great was the crush that a great many people were turned away.

PARIS, Oct. 2. -- The holding of the Dreyfus demonstration organized by M. Pressenoe, one of the leaders in the agitation, for this afternoon, was prevented by the closing of the Salle Wagram. M. Pressenoe and his friends tried to force an entrance, and an uproar resulted.
The Rev. J. O. Wilson, pastor of St. Andrew's Church, in West Seventy-sixth Street, and Chaplain of the Fourteenth Regiment, last night preached what he described a "semi-political" sermon.

The third business quarter of 1898 ended on Saturday. Nine months of a truly wonderful year passed with that day. During those months great progress has marked the course of American business affairs -- progress that has been all the more remarkable because of the war with Spain and the other disturbances against which American commerce has had to contend.

THE PLOT OF ANARCHISTS AND MEASURES FOR THEIR SUPPRESSION. -- According to the St. Petersburg correspondent of the Politische Correspondenz of Berlin there should be no doubt that there is an Anarchists' "club" in New York City that has perfected plans for "removing" all the crowned heads of Europe.

QUEBEC, Oct. 2. -- During the last twenty-four hours the American members of the International Commission have received many telegrams from different parts of the United States, and particularly from Seattle, asking about the cession of American territory to give the Canadians freer access to the Yukon River in Alaska.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 2. -- The programme of the closing day of the convention of the Brotherhood of St. Andrew included communion services in a number of churches, the annual sermon in Emmanuel Church, preached by the Rev. Dr. William S. Rainsford of St. George's Church, New York; public meetings at Music Hall this afternoon and evening, and the farewell meeting at Music Hall to-night.

Golfers will unusually active this week. Many events of importance will take place. On local links there will be something in progress every day. The women golfers throughout the country who are intending to compete next week for the championship of the United States will be deeply interested in the announcement of entries for this important contest.

Of all the noted localities in Boston, none is richer in old-time associations than the North End and among the many quaint old streets, lanes, and alleys round which cluster the historic memories of this part of the city, Marshall Street, leading by a short cut from Hanover Street to Union Street, and known in earlier days as Marshall's Lane, is one of the quaintest and oldest.

SANTIAGO DE CUBA, Oct. 2. -- Surgeon Major Seaman of the transport Obdam declares that there will be a repetition of the awful horrors that have characterized the voyage home of the other transports if more sick soldiers are sent on board the vessel for transportation to New York.

BUFFALO, Oct. 2. -- Ole N. Snyder, the nominee for Attorney General on the Independent Chicago platform ticket, has declined to accept the nomination. In an interview this afternoon Mr. Snyder said: "I will not accept the nomination. My decision is final, and a telegram of declination will be in Mr. McDonald's hands to-morrow morning. That is all I can say."

Morris Park's Fall meeting was ushered in Saturday with a programme that was all any lover of racing could desire. There was quality as well as quantity in the six races, and four of the events were fixtures. It was what the speculative public called a hard day, for only one favorite won, and that in the hurdle race, which is never a big betting affair.

The Fall season of harness racing in the West and Southwest is developing more remarkable performances in the line of speed than any which the Grand Circuit contests produced. More records were broken at Louisville last week than at any previous meeting this year, and one name was added to the 2:10 trotting list.

SEA GIRT, Oct. 2. -- The officers of the First New Jersey Regiment, who are recruiting three companies from that command for transfer to the Fourth Regiment, which is slated for duty in Cuba with Gen. Graham's Second Corps, expect to have the recruits in camp by to-morrow evening, and Col. Smith contemplates moving the Fourth to Camp Meade early next week.

The road was quite lively yesterday, especially in the afternoon, and the extra mounted policemen detailed under Superintendent Quinn to look after the drivers and runaways, had their hands full.

Gen. William R. Shafter arrived in the city yesterday from Montauk Point. He will go to Governors Island this mornng to take command of the Department of the East. He was accompanied by Major J.D. Miley, his aide, and a valet.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- The phenomenally low price of cotton recently reported, said to be the lowest point reached in many years, lends special interest to a series of tables just compiled by the Treasury Bureau of Statistics showing the remarkable increase in cotton production and coincidental fall in price.

MANILA, Oct. 2. -- The National Assembly at Malolos at a recent sitting voted Aguinaldo a civil list of $75,000, but Aguinaldo declined to receive anything until the army should have been paid. An attempt was made by Paterne, the Speaker of the House, to have inserted a clause granting him an allowance because of his office, but the proposal was rejected.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Oct. 2. -- For fifteen hours, from 3 o'clock this morning until 6 o'clock to-night, Savannah has been in the grasp of a West Indian storm. During that time the wind blew steadily from fifty to seventy miles an hour. While the city escaped with comparatively little damage, the loss of property among the sea islands of the Georgia and South Carolina coasts is believed to be heavy.

Some of them may go to Cuba, but the majority will for the present occupy the new camps recently selected in Georgia and South Carolina. It is thought that troops sent to garrison duty in Cuba will not remain long, but when they have seen service for a few months will return to this country.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 3. -- Prof. W.B. Scott, who occupies the Chair of Geology in Princeton University, has received notice that at the annual meeting at Bristol, England, last month of the British Association for the Advancement of Science he was made a corresponding member.

Very much has been made by the opponents of all expansion of the territory of the United States of the argument that it must logically and practically undermine the American policy known as the Monroe doctrine. According to this argument expansion involves us in the complications of European countries, which we cannot enter while excluding all European nations from any influence upon our own policy.

LONDON, Oct. 3. -- Dr. Nancy Guilford the midwife, of Bridgeport, Conn., or the woman suspected of being Dr. Guilford, was remanded at Bow Street Police Court here to-day for a week after evidence tending to prove her identity with the woman who landed at Liverpool last week from the steamer Vancouver had been presented.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 3. -- Gov. Stephens, Police Commissioner Hawes, and Chief of Police Campbell, who have inaugurated a war on the usurers of this city, have returned from New York, where they went to see officials of the Western Union Telegraph Company and get them to rescind a rule under which employes were discharged when served with a garnishment.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3. -- Senator James K. Jones of Arkansas, Chairman of the National Democratic Committee, has appointed ex-Gov. William J. Stone of Missouri; ex-Gov. John P. Altgeld of Illinois; Senator William V. Allen of Nebraska, and Senator Henry M. Teller of Colorado to act in conjunction with himself as a committee on ways and means.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3. -- Augustin Daly presented at the Chestnut Street Theatre this evening a prose translation of "Cyrano de Bergerac." This translation is reasonably faithful in form. As for the performance, it is not inspired, and to-night it was lacking in certainty and romantic elevation.

Until the sixth inning in the game between the Brooklyns and Washingtons at Washington Park, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, it looked as though the home team would come out victorious. In this inning, however, McKenna, who pitched splendidly in the previous innings, seemed to lose all his cunning and the visitors kept the Brooklyn team chasing base hits for about ten minutes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- The entry of American pork at German Custom Houses without certificates of its freedom from trichinosis, the officials of the Agricultural Department say, is the fault entirely of the Custom Department of the German Government, and is not to be attributed in any way to a lack of diligence of the department's agents.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Oct. 3. -- A notable audience was present to-night at the Lafayette Square Theatre, including Mrs. McKinley and party from the White House, John Addison Porter, the Attorney General, the members of the commission now investigating the conduct of the war, and many social leaders.

WICHITA, Kan., Oct. 3. -- Of all the strange phenomena that have ever been observed in this section it seems the most unprecedented occurred here to-day in the form of an enormous swarm of butterflies. The day was extremely hot and unusually still. Only two other days in the year registered a higher degree of heat, the thermometer standing 104 in the shade at 2 o'clock.

We note with interest that Gen. SHAFTER expresses a good opinion of Col. ROOSEVELT and approves his candidacy. The public would be much more interested, however, in Col. ROOSEVELT'S opinion of Gen. SHAFTER and his generalship.

W.B. Taylor Sons have sold for Collins Collins the four-story brownstone-front dwelling 603 Fifth Avenue, 22.5 by 100. Significance is added to this sale by the report on Saturday that No. 599 had been sold through the same firm of brokers. The buyer's name is withheld in both cases.

The Democrats will open their campaign to-day by the notification of the candiates nominated at the Syracuse convention. Preparatory work has been in progress ever since the ticket was put up, and even prior to that, but the open and vigorous work will be initiated by Justice Augustus Van Wyck to-night in his brief speech of acceptance.

Dr. DE COSTA'S statement of facts concerning the religious life of this Nation is of a nature to give occasion for grave concern to churchmen. Only two-sevenths of the people of the United States, it appears, are church members. There are fifty millions outside the church. Dr. DE COSTA thinks this is an appalling evidence of the spread of irreligion in the land.

ALBANY, Oct. 3. -- The next Governor of the State will have a large amount of patronage at his disposal. He will be shorn of his present large military staff, which will after Jan. 1 next consist of an Adjutant General, a Military Secretary, and fourteen Aides de Camp, of whom ten are to be selected from the officers of the Guard and Naval Militia.

HAVANA, Oct. 2. -- Lieuts. Wade and Marsh returned from Matanzas to-day. Their mission was in connection with the relief supplies brought on the steamer Comal. Ten thousand rations were asked for the Cuban camps and 30,000 were given.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 3. -- There seems to be little doubt that the Democratic Convention to-morrow will nominate Alexander B. Bruce of Lawrence for Governor and Edward J. Slattery of South Framingham for the second place on the ticket.

" The interest of parents in their soldier sons is exhibited in various ways," said a clerk in the Adjutant General's office to a Star reporter, "and while some of these exhibitions are grand and beautiful, some are otherwise, and I am sorry to say that the otherwise kind are painfully frequent. A recent case will explain what I am getting at.

DENVER, Col., Oct. 3. -- At to-day's session of the court-martial trial of the Rev. Joseph P. McIntyre of the battleship Oregon, for sensational charges against brother officers of the navy, made in a lecture delivered in Denver Aug. 8, the chaplain went on the stand in his own defense. His testimony is intended to establish a plea of irresponsibility for his utterances on the occasion.

It has been a source of great comfort to War Department officials and their friends that in answer to numberless charges of incompetency and neglect they could answer, "But the regulars don't complain!" At every lull in the storm of criticism somebody has piped this pretty phrase as shrilly as possible, evidently believing that if it were repeated often enough the public would finally turn at least a portion of its indignation against the volunteers.

Modern Mexico, a publication designed to call the attention of American manufacturers, merchants, and investors to the opportunities that exist for them in the republic across the Rio Grande, discusses the subject of "Health in the Tropics" from the standpoints of experience and common sense.

The Democrats of Brooklyn made their Congressional nominations last night, except in the Fifth District, where an adjournment was taken. In every case the nomination was made without friction, and entire harmony reigned. The candidates are:

The above notice appeared yesterday morning. The live steer was picked up last Wednesday afternoon swimming aimlessly about in the middle of the North River, off Christopher Street. He is still alive and well, and unceasingly endeavoring to appease an appetite that is causing his rescuers to make strenuous efforts to find the owner.

Another golf triumph was scored yesterday by the women of the Morris County Club in a team contest with six of their sister golfers from the Morristown Field Club. The latter organization contains the younger players, but several of them, as Miss Bryce, Miss Kip, and Miss Willis, have lately become eligible as members of the more pretentious golf club, and have been a valuable addition to its talent.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- The decision of the Secretary of the Navy that no present relief can be granted to officers of the navy from the hardships inflicted by the "leapfrog" system of promotions made possible under the statutes, does not entirely discourage naval officers from hoping that Congress will grant some compensation for what they regard as legalized injustice.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- Secretary Alger to-day announced that Savannah, Ga., had been selected as the point of embarkation of all troops which may hereafter be sent to Cuba or Puerto Rico. It is stated at the War Department that Savannah was selected because it afforded the best facilities.

The First Battalion of the One Hundred and Ninth Regiment, commanded by Major W.W. Marks, spent yesterday on the shooting ranges at Creedmoor. Three-fourths of the men in the battalion had never been on a shooting range before, and therefore the number of qualifications was small. The battalion comprised Companies A, B, C, E, and F, 163 men. The scores of those who qualified follow:

PARIS, Oct 3. -- To-day's session of the Peace Commissioners lasted until 4 o'clock, at which hour the Commissioners adjourned to meet at 2 o'clock next Friday afternoon, such an interval being desirable and necessary to allow separate consideration by each commission of matters requiring similar consideration before the joint commission.

There is a thief safely locked up in this city who will have reason to remember Joseph Harper of the publishing firm of Harper Brothers for some time to come. It is not often that a millionaire has the opporunity of capturing and handing over a malefactor to an officer of the law unaided, but this uncommon opportunity came to Hr. Harper yesterday morning.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3. -- A.P. Swineford, ex-Governor of Alaska, who is in Chicago, declares the prospectors who have returned goldless from that region were unsuccessful because of lack of foresight in failing to properly prepare for a search for a fortune in the new country.

The Chicago Platform Democrats had much to trouble them yesterday, but for every seeming blow to the party organization a remedy was soon found. Henry George, son of the late famous single taxer of the same name, sent a letter in which he said he could not accept the nomination for Governor, and H.M. McDonald, who presided at the convention which selected Mr. George, was quickly named to fill the vacancy.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 3. -- The famous "Little Town" elections were held in Connecticut to-day, 162 of the 168 towns in the State electing officials of the town governments, in many cases voting on the liquor license question, and in a few instances settling permanently or temporarily the question involving the abandonment of the district school system in favor of consolidated schools under town auspices.

Justice Cohen, in the Supreme Court, yesterday, confirmed the inquisition of a Sheriff's jury had before a commission that Mrs. Harriet Beach Rogers is insane. Justice Cohen holds that the evidence was ample to justify the verdict of the jury.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- The President has appointed David J. Hill of Rochester First Assistant Secretary of State, to succeed John Bassett Moore, resigned. Dr. Hill is now in Holland, but is expected to return at once, having accepted the position tendered.

JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 3. -- No additional cases of yellow fever have been reported to-day. There is no panic, but more of the people are leaving for northern points. Several of the State officials have already gone, and more will leave to-day or to-morrow, and, with two or three exceptions, the State House will be deserted.

LONDON, Oct. 3. -- At the first day's racing of the Nottingham Autumn meeting today, Capt. A.E. Whitaker's Variety gelding, by Peter Flower, finished second, in the race for the Lenton Firs Plate, with Tod Sloane up. This race is a high-weight handicap of 106 sovereigns, for three-year-olds and upward; entrance, 3 sovereigns; the second to save entrance out of the plate.

Prof. RICHMOND MAYO-SMITH publishes in the latest number of The Political Science Quarterly an article on "The Movement of Prices," which not only is extremely interesting, but may fairly be called illuminating. It is to be followed by further discussion, and we strongly urge business men and financiers, to whom this question in its larger bearings must be of importance, to follow carefully the professor's treatment of it.

ALBANY, Oct. 3. -- The New York Gas and Electric Light, Heat and Power Company of New York City to-day filed with the Secretary of State a certificate of incorporation. It is organized with a capital of $25,000,000. The Directors are Henry J. Hemmens, Frank D. Allen, F.L. Allen, J. F. Yawger, Louis M. King, C.N. Flint, and N.W. Smith of New York City.

The question who shall succeed Col. HAY in London is one of high if not of the highest importance. It is highly desirable that our representative in London shall, by his character, equipment, and associations strengthen the impression that has been made by Col. HAY and by Mr. BAYARD, and which has had very much to do with the existing era of good feeling between Great Britain and the United States.

The fear of the Ninth Regiment men that they would not after all be mustered out as promised when they left Camp Thomas a few weeks ago, has been intensified within the past twenty-four hours by the news of a secret meeting called by Col. J.G. Greene to arrange for keeping the regiment in service for the full period of its enlistment.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- The Treasury Department has information that importations at a number of ports of the United States, under the immediate transportation acts are improperly combined in entries to avoid the payment of the stamp tax.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- Although the Republicans are of the opinion that they will win in the Congressional elections, and so maintain their control of Congress and enable the Administration to carry out its policy without embarrassment, it is evident that Senator Hanna plainly shares the anxiety of the campaign managers lest something has happened to deprive the dominant party of a share of the approval of the voters.

The men who made Theodore Roosevelt the Republican candidate for Governor and the men who fought him and tried to renominate Frank S. Black sat down together in an upper room of the Republican Club, 450 Fifth Avenue, last evening. It was a meeting of pacification, preliminary to the notification to-day and the ratification tomorrow night.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3. -- Senator Matthew S. Quay and his son Richard appeared before Magistrate Jermon this afternoon and gave bail in the sum of $5,000 each for their appearance on Thursday to answer a charge alleged against them of conspiracy to misuse the funds of the Commonwealth. David H. Lane became surety for both men.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 3. -- An evening paper says:

The Rough Riders' tournament, which was advertised to begin at the American Horse Exchange this evening, has been abandoned. Mrs. Geraldine Bailey was so informed by a committee of Rough Riders that called upon her at the Hoffman House last evening.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- All the members of the War Investigating Commission were present at to-day's session except ex-Gov. Beaver, and the announcement was made that he would be in attendance to-morrow, when Gen. Wheeler will be present as the first witness before the commission.

BRUNSWICK, Ga., Oct. 3. -- During the tropical hurricane of Sunday, a tidal wave was driven in from the sea and inundated for an average depth of five feet practically every business house and warehouse in this city.

Barnard College is out of debt. The last $6,000 necessary to enable the institution to start its Fall term yesterday owing no man anything, was pledged to George A. Plimpton, the Treasurer, in the evening. This means that Barnard will get the $100,000 endowment fund which was anonymously given on condition that the college should be debtfree by Oct. 3.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Sept. 26. -- The American Commissioners to arrange for the evacuation of Puerto Rico have been eminently successful in their dealings with the Spanish Commissioners, and it is believed that within three weeks at the furthest the last of the Spanish troops will have sailed for home, and the Stars and Stripes will be unfurled over San Juan.

PONCE, Puerto Rico, Sept. 27. -- It is the well-grounded and almost unanimous opinion of the medical staff of the American Army in Puerto Rico that the condition of the volunteer forces here necessitates their removal North. Sickness is increasing and has been increasing during the past three weeks at an alarming rate.

" Cyrano de Bergerac," Edmond Rostand's famous play, which has revived the hope of poetic drama in France, and will doubtless eventually give its author a seat among the forty immortals, was acted in English for the first time, at the Garden Theatre last evening.

Columbia University began its one hundred and forty-fifth working year yesterday morning, with services in the chapel, in the Schermerhorn Building. With President Seth Low upon the platform was the Chaplain, the Rev. Dr. George R. Van De Water, Chaplain also of the Seventy-first Regiment. In the course of his opening address, President Low said:

CHICAGO, Oct. 4. -- On Oct. 15 L. Z. Leiter and his family will desert the old house at 4 Tower Court and move into one of the great palaces of Michigan Boulevard, the residence of Mrs. George Middleton, who will go to the Pacific Coast for the Winter in search of health.

Standing on the veranda of his hill-perched home on the shores of Oyster Bay yesterday afternoon Col. Theodore Roosevelt received official information of his nomination for Governor from the committee to whom that duty had been delegated by the Republican State Convention.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Oct. 4. -- Amid the enthusiastic plaudits of nearly 40,000 intensely interested people, the shrill salutation of steam whistles from many boats and tugs, and the strains of "The Star-Spangled Banner," the first-class battleship Illinois slid into the water to-day. The launch was a brilliant success in every particular, the mechanism and preparations being perfect.

Conventions for the nomination of candidates for the Assembly were held last night by the Republicans in the various districts of the Boroughs of Manhattan, the Bronx, and Brooklyn. A man was chosen in each of the twenty-one Brooklyn districts, but on this side the river many of the conventions failed to agree, and adjourned without naming the candidates.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- A report was current to-night that the Philippine agent Agoncillo, who recently arrived in this country representing the insurgent Government, had been refused recognition by the President. It was impossible, however, to obtain from any authoritative scource information on the subject.

It is incredible that the statesmen in Madrid can be sincerely "stupefied" at the suggestion that we may demand possession of the Philippines. They pretend to be stupefied at the suggestion that we shall insist upon retaining even the Island of Luzon, or even the city and harbor of Manila.
SAVANNAH, Ga., Oct. 4. -- Complete details from Brunswick and surrounding country are impossible, because of the prostration of the telegraph and telephone systems.

It is refreshing to learn that immediately on receiving official intimation -- which was promptly sent by our Minister -- that there was a possibility of dangerous confusion at Pekin, the Administration ordered the cruiser Baltimore and the gunboat Petrel to be sent from Manila to the nearest accessible point to the Chinese capital.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Oct. 4. -- Mrs. T.W. Keene, widow of the tragedian, has lost $40,000 in the stock company and Robinson's Opera House here, and is now in New York trying to secure more capital. On her return next week she will decide whether to continue the stock company or not. Manager Eagleson and actors -- Henrietta Vaders, Lida McMillan, and Charles Stewart -- have left the company.

Henry Morgenthau has bought from Thomas L. Watt a tract of about fifty lots, covering the block front on the east side of Seventh Avenue, between One Hundred and Thirty-eighth and One Hundred and Thirty-ninth Streets and extending 625 feet in depth on either street. The price paid is reported at $300,000.

In bringing charges against Gen. COLLIS and his deputies the Mayor's Commissioners of Accounts have attacked the administration of Mayor STRONG at its most vulnerable point. The Department of Public Works was notoriously the weakest, least defensible, and most unsatisfactory part of the Strong administration.

Two soldiers who had been undergoing treatment at St. John's Hospital, Long Island City, told Major Appel, the Surgeon at the Army Building, that they had been compelled to pay $1 each for a discharge from St. John's Hospital. The soldiers were Andrew C. Kitchen of the Second Infantry, and Henry R. Smith of the Tenth Infantry.

The yearly meeting of the trustees of the Peabody Educational Fund was held yesterday afternoon at the Fifth Avenue Hotel. Chief Justice Melville W. Fuller presided in the place of William M. Evarts, whose health has been such that he has been unable to attend the meetings for several years.

Chaplain MCINTYRE'S narrative of hardships undergone by him while on the Oregon is not a little impressive, and it would not have been surprising if the anxieties of the long voyage and the excitements of a great battle had reduced the clerical sailorman to a state of weakness and incoherency.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 4. -- The Democrats of the Second Assembly District of Westchester County to-day nominated William Henderson of Westchester for member of Assembly. August J. Beyer of Harrison received 32 votes to Henderson's 44.

Wood was in command of the battalion, which was composed of Companies D, G, H, and K, comprising 130 men, most of whom were recruits.
